intro: Lepidium remyi, commonly known as the Mexican peppergrass, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cress plants, and is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and pinnately divided leaves. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in disturbed areas such as roadsides and fields. Lepidium remyi is an annual herb that produces small, oval-shaped seeds, which are dispersed by wind and animals. Its botanical features make it a notable species in arid and semi-arid ecosystems.
